body:
Thanks for reporting, @sameermahajan - which forecaster are you using? Can you past your `forecaster=` specification?

FYI @aiwalter, @mloning

my suspicion is that your series index is not compatible with your forecasting horizon - both should have the same index type.

Could you check whether `series.index` is a `PeriodIndex` with `freq="H"`?
What is `freq` of data? Looks the index is not complete

I am using AutoETS forecaster. My complete script that you can run with the .csv file that I have uploaded here to repro the issue is:

``` python
import pandas as pd
d = pd.read_csv('172.17.110.3_172.17.110.4_1974_6_octet.csv')
b = d.groupby(["ds"]).y.sum().reset_index()
b['ds'] = pd.to_datetime(b['ds'])
b['y'] = b['y'].astype(float)
series = pd.Series(b.y.values, index=b.ds)
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon
fh = ForecastingHorizon(
    pd.PeriodIndex(pd.date_range(start="2021-10-17 18:37:32", periods=24, freq="H")), is_relative=False
)
from sktime.forecasting.ets import AutoETS
forecaster = AutoETS(auto=True, sp=12, n_jobs=-1)
forecaster.fit(series)
y_pred = forecaster.predict(fh)
```

In my use case the only data points that are available to train the model are in the .csv

I believe my index on Series might be DatatimeIndex. Please feel free to suggest any modifications  to my code to get it working e.g. any other data  type for ds column in pandas Dataframe, any  other way to create pandas Series from pandas Dataframe etc.

To use PeriodIndex I tried adding:

``` python
b.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(b.ds)
series = pd.Series(b.y.values, index=b.index.to_period("S"))
```

but then I get the error as below. I can  specify  different value for start if that is what is  required. I only want to predict for the next day. At this time I am not worried about exact times for which it is predicted  but it has to be for every hour.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AssertionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-19-262dab6424c0> in <module>
      6 forecaster = AutoETS(auto=True, sp=12, n_jobs=-1)
      7 forecaster.fit(series)
----> 8 y_pred = forecaster.predict(fh)
      9 plot_series(series, y_pred, labels=["y", "y_pred"])

~/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py in predict(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
    236         # alpha = check_alpha(alpha)
    237 
--> 238         y_pred = self._predict(
    239             self.fh,
    240             X=X_inner,

~/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_statsmodels.py in _predict(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
     81         # statsmodels requires zero-based indexing starting at the
     82         # beginning of the training series when passing integers
---> 83         start, end = fh.to_absolute_int(self._y.index[0], self.cutoff)[[0, -1]]
     84 
     85         if "exog" in inspect.signature(self._forecaster.__init__).parameters.keys():

~/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_fh.py in to_absolute_int(self, start, cutoff)
    338         # to convert the horizon to the absolute representation below
    339         absolute = self.to_absolute(cutoff).to_pandas()
--> 340         _check_start(start, absolute)
    341 
    342         # Note: We should here also coerce to periods for more reliable arithmetic

~/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_fh.py in _check_start(start, index)
    500     if isinstance(index, pd.PeriodIndex):
    501         assert isinstance(start, pd.Period)
--> 502         assert index.freqstr == start.freqstr
    503 
    504     if isinstance(index, pd.DatetimeIndex):

AssertionError:

rename.from: [BUG] AssertionError while predicting over a forecasting horizon
rename.to: [BUG] AssertionError when using `pd.PeriodIntex` forecasting horizon with `freq="H"`

rename.from: [BUG] AssertionError when using `pd.PeriodIntex` forecasting horizon with `freq="H"`
rename.to: [BUG] AssertionError when using `pd.PeriodIndex` forecasting horizon with `freq="H"`

body:
I had a look into your issue, and it seems your input data is at unevenly spaced intervals. 

In order to predict at hourly intervals, you would first have to aggregate your input data to a regular hourly frequency. For example, you could aggregate all data points within each hour. 

When done, you should be able to predict future values at an hourly interval. Does that help?

In my case, I don't have control over when the data arrives and I want to model time as closely as when it arrives exactly. Also, my data works perfectly with another open-source namely Fbprophet and gives me hourly predictions which looked reasonable. Not sure whether it does hourly aggregation as you are suggesting under the cover...
@niekvanderlaan, can you confirm your diagnosis in more detail, please? E.g., what is the precise condition for which error/behaviour to occur?

The condition for this particular error is the mismatch between the frequency of the input data and the desired output frequency, i.e. Seconds and Hourly frequencies. Therefore, in order to resolve it, one would have to provide an input that is as hourly.

Now, in this case, converting the input data to hourly is not trivial due to the unevenly spaced data. I am not aware of any functionality in sktime that is able to deal with such unevenly spaced or sparsed time series. As for Fbprophet, it is a possibility that they are dealing with it, or they are simply not checking for the frequencies to match, but I wouldn't know.

Does that help clarify?

>Also, my data works perfectly with another open-source namely Fbprophet and gives me hourly predictions which looked reasonable. Not sure whether it does hourly aggregation as you are suggesting under the cover...

@sameermahajan, `sktime` interfaces `fbprophet` via the `Prophet` forecaster, so it would be useful to compare. I.e., how do the following behave when providing discrepant frequencies:
* the `sktime` `Prophet` adapter
* the `fbprophet` functionality

For `AutoETS`, it may simply be that that forecaster cannot handle unequal frequencies in `y` and `fh`. Then, we may want to resolve this by adding functionality to return informative error messages for the forecasters that can't.
